page.title: 03The Boot Inn
page.content: The inn is known to have existed in 1632 when it was the first, or last staging-post on the Salisbury-Bath stage-coach run. It has been suggested that The Boot is so named as it was on the pilgrim route to the shrine of John Schorn, a Buckinghamshire parish priest whose prayers were said to be effective against blindness, toothache and gout and who was said to have conjured the Devil into a Boot. The present tenants are determined to preserve the unique atmosphere of this pub:no modern furnishings, but a scrubbed wooden floor and wooden fittings. No juke-box either, as the clientele are encouraged to play the traditional games of Shove-halfpenny, Darts, Crib, Dominoes or Bar Skittles. Only tradional ales,drawn from the wood, are served.
